{{Infobox weapon | name = Whitehead Mark 5 torpedo | image = | caption = | origin = {{flag|Austria-Hungary}} | type = [[Anti-surface warfare|Anti-surface ship]] [[torpedo]]{{cite web | title = Torpedo History: Whitehead Torpedo Mk1 | url= http://www.history.navy.mil/museums/keyport/html/part2.htm | accessdate = 10 June 2013}} | is_ranged = yes | is_explosive = yes | is_missile = yes | service = 1910â€“1922 | used_by = {{navy|United States}}{{cite web|url=http://navalunderseamuseum.org/media/6c06204b6731dd48ffff8336ffffe906.pdf|title=Artifact Spotlight: Whitehead torpedo|accessdate=8 June 2013}} | wars = | designer = [[Robert Whitehead]] | manufacturer = Torpedofabrik Whitehead & Co.{{cite web | title = Chronology: Torpedo in Word and Picture | url= http://www.muzej-rijeka.hr/torpedo/en/chronology.html | accessdate = 2013-06-08}}
[[Naval Torpedo Station]]
[[Vickers Limited]] | design_date = 1901 | weight = 1452 pounds | length = 204 inches (5.18 meters) | diameter = 17.7 inches (45 centimeters) | range = 1000-4000 yards | filling = wet [[guncotton]] | filling_weight = 200 pounds | detonation = War Nose Mk 5 contact exploder | engine = 4-cylinder [[Reciprocating engine|reciprocating]] | speed = 27-40 knots | guidance = [[gyroscope]] | launch_platform = [[battleship]]s, [[torpedo boat]]s and [[submarine]]s }} The '''Whitehead Mark 5 torpedo''' was a [[Whitehead torpedo]] adopted by the [[United States Navy]] for use in an [[Anti-surface warfare|anti-surface ship]] role in 1910. The Mark 5 was the first torpedo to be manufactured by a foreign company, the Whitehead facility in the [[United Kingdom]],{{cite web | title = United States of America, Torpedoes Pre-World War II | url=http://www.navweaps.com/Weapons/WTUS_PreWWII.htm | accessdate = 25 June 2013}} and in 1908, by the [[Naval Torpedo Station]] in [[Newport, Rhode Island]]. It was also the first torpedo to allow the firing ship to vary its speed and range. ==Characteristics== The Mark 5 was a "hot-running" (powered by heated air) torpedo, as opposed to previous Whitehead designs, which were "cold-running". It was similar in performance to the [[Bliss-Leavitt torpedo]]es of that era. Around 500 units were produced by the Naval Torpedo Station and [[Vickers Limited]]. The Mark 5 had variable speed; at a high speed of 40 knots, it had a range of 1000 yards. A low speed of 27 knots allowed the weapon a range of 4000 yards; at medium speed of 36 knots, its range was 2000 yards. This variable speed was set before loading the torpedo in its [[torpedo tube|tube]] by adjusting the reducing valve. The Mark 5 was, however, overshadowed by the increasing efficiency and range of [[Bliss-Leavitt torpedo]]es. In 1922, all torpedoes prior to the [[Bliss-Leavitt Mark 7 torpedo]] in the US Navy's inventory were condemned in favor of more modern versions. The Mark 5 was launched from [[battleship]]s, [[torpedo boat]]s and [[submarine]]s. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Mark-series torpedoes}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Whitehead Mark 5 torpedo}} [[Category:Torpedoes]] [[Category:Torpedoes of the United States]] [[Category:Unmanned underwater vehicles]] [[Category:Whitehead torpedoes]]
